en_first_half: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the
en_second_half: Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (Mem., I must ask the Count all about them.)
en_results_raw: Magyar tribes settled in Hungary in the tenth century, they found the Szekelys already there, a people as distinct in their language and customs as they were in their traditions of origin. The Szekelys, according to their own legends, were the bodyguard of Attila, and when he fell, they fled from the advancing Huns and settled in the fastnesses of the Eastern Carpathians. There they maintained their independence, and when the Magyars came, they did not attempt to subjugate them, but entered into a compact of alliance. The Szekelys, therefore, are a people by themselves, and their country, which is a mountainous tract between the Transylvanian Alps and the Moldau, is as difficult of access as it is picturesque. It is a land of deep, narrow valleys, dense forests, and rugged peaks, and its people are as primitive and independent as their surroundings. They are a brave and warlike race, and their customs and manners are peculiar to themselves. They are intensely loyal to the King of Hungary, and have preserved their nationality and independence through the centuries, in spite of the efforts of their more powerful neighbors to subdue them. Their language is a curious mixture of Hungarian and Roumanian, with a sprinkling of words derived from the ancient Dacian. They are Greek Catholics, and their priests are allowed to marry. Their villages are scattered over the mountain slopes, and each one is a little republic, governed by its own elders. The Szekelys are a people of marked individuality, and their country is one of the most romantic and picturesque in Europe.

Tôi sẽ nghỉ lại cùng những người Szekely. Nghe nói họ xuất thân từ Attila và là hậu duệ của người Hung nô. Có lẽ điều này là có thật bởi vì vào thế kỷ thứ mười hai, khi người Magyard đi chinh phục xứ

Dường như mọi mê tín dị đoan trên thế giới đều có ở vùng Carpates, và tất cả luôn làm khuấy động trí tưởng tượng của dân gian. Attila ve Hunların soyundan geldiklerini iddia eden son grubun arasına gidiyorum. Bu iddia doğru olabilir zira Macarlar

tr_results_raw: Transilvanya'nın tarihi, bu çeşitli etnik grupların etkileşimleriyle zenginleşti. Macarlar, batı bölgesindeki en büyük etnik grubudur ve genellikle bölgenin ekonomik ve siyasi hayatına büyük bir katkı sağlamaktadır. Güneydeki Saksonlar ise genellikle doğal kaynaklarına ve hayvancılığına bağlıdır. Eflakliler ise daha az sayıda ve genellikle dağlık bölgelerde yer alırlar. Sekeller ise Transilvanya'nın kuzey ve doğu kısmında yer alırlar ve genellikle hayvancılık ve bitki üretimiyle ilgilenirler. Attila ve Hunlar gibi eski Türk ticaret yolu ve askeri faaliyetlerinin nedeniyle bu bölgeye giren Türk kökenli gruplar, tarihi etnik yapısı üzerinde derin bir etki bırakmıştır. Bu gruplar, zamanla Macarlarla karıştıktan sonra Transilvanya'nın sosyal yapısına derin bir önyargı yaratmışlardır. Bu etnik çeşitliliği, bölgede yaşanan coğrafi ve ekonomik farklılıkları da yansıtır. Transilvanya'nın geleceğinde bu etnik diversite, uluslararası ilişkileri ve iç politikaları etkileyebilecek önemli bir faktördür.

en_first_half: 4 May.—I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened
en_second_half: sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.

en_first_half: I handed to him the sealed letter which Mr. Hawkins had entrusted to me. He opened it and read it gravely; then,
en_second_half: with a charming smile, he handed it to me to read. One passage of it, at least, gave me a thrill of pleasure.
en_results_raw: he looked up at me with a serious expression, "This changes everything. Mr. Hawkins has requested a meeting at the earliest convenience. We must prepare accordingly. The contents of this letter are of utmost importance and confidentiality is paramount. I trust you understand the gravity of the situation." His tone was firm, yet there was a hint of concern in his eyes. "We need to gather all relevant documents and ensure that our strategy is watertight. This could be the turning point we've been waiting for, or it could be a trap. Either way, we must proceed with caution." He stood up, signaling the end of our discussion, and added, "Let's reconvene in my office in an hour. We have much to prepare before Hawkins' arrival." With that, he briskly walked out of the room, leaving me with a whirlwind of thoughts and a sense of urgency that was palpable.

"Tôi không thể tin rằng họ đã gửi đi đến cuối cuộc đời của mình. Lời chúc mừng sinh nhật và những câu chuyện cổ tích đã làm tôi nhớ lại những khoảnh khắc đẹp đẽ với con gái tôi." Lão nhìn nhận lá thư một cách mơ hồ, một lúc nghĩ đến quê hương cổ, lúc khác hình bóng về thời gian qua. Tôi cảm thấy lòng nhớ sâu sắc đang lan rộng trong không gian và cảm thấy mình đang làm một điều quan trọng, một việc giúp đỡ một người cố gắng vượt qua đau đớn của cuộc đời.

en_first_half: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thought—that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence. How was it that all the
en_second_half: people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it.
